evidence: Here’s a straightforward MATLAB example to show linear convolution in action.
We use MATLAB’s built-in conv function to compute their linear convolution:
The process is exactly the same here; only the input sequences are different.
When we plot the result, we see the familiar triangular shape.
It rises as the two signals increasingly overlap, reaches a peak when their centers align, and then falls as the overlap decreases.

evidence: Here’s a straightforward MATLAB example to show linear convolution in action.
The process is exactly the same here; only the input sequences are different.
MATLAB makes it very easy to visualize convolution, and seeing the result in a plot helps reinforce what’s happening mathematically.
